image.altText: An aerial view of houses in Hobart, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In his second-last meeting as RBA governor, Philip Lowe says there may be significant challenges on the horizon that may make taming inflation tricky — namely, service price inflation. He said the recent data is consistent with inflation returning back to the RBA's target band. "There are though significant uncertainties," he said. " Services price inflation has been surprisingly persistent overseas and the same could occur in Australia. " There are also uncertainties regarding the lags in the operation of monetary policy and how firms' pricing decisions and wages will respond to the slowing in the economy at a time when the labour market remains tight. "The outlook for household consumption is also an ongoing source of uncertainty."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Significant uncertainties' still face the Australian economy, Lowe says

children.content: In his second-last meeting as RBA governor,
Philip Lowe
says there may be
significant challenges on the horizon
that may make taming inflation tricky — namely,
service price inflation
He said the recent data is consistent with inflation returning back to the RBA's target band.
"There are though significant uncertainties," he said.
Services price inflation has been surprisingly persistent overseas and the same could occur in Australia
There are also uncertainties regarding the lags in the operation of monetary policy
and how firms' pricing decisions and wages will respond to the slowing in the economy at a time when the labour market remains tight.
"The outlook for household consumption is also an ongoing source of uncertainty."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe says the board decided to leave the cash rate unchanged at 4.1% to give them more time to assess the impact of past rate rises. "The higher interest rates are working to establish a more sustainable balance between supply and demand in the economy and will continue to do so," he said in a statement. "In light of this and the uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook, the Board again decided to hold interest rates steady this month. "This will provide further time to assess the impact of the increase in interest rates to date and the economic outlook."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA left rates on hold to give them more time to assess past hikes

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe
says the board decided to leave the cash rate unchanged at 4.1% to give them more time to assess the impact of past rate rises.
"The higher interest rates are working to establish a more sustainable balance between supply and demand in the economy and will continue to do so," he said in a statement.
"In light of this and the uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook, the Board again decided to hold interest rates steady this month.
"This will
provide further time to assess the impact of the increase in interest rates to date
and the economic outlook."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Despite hitting the pause button again this month, the RBA says another rate rise might be on the cards in the future. RBA governor Philip Lowe says that all depends on how quickly inflation returns to that all-important 2-3% target. Here's some of what he had to say in his statement: "Some further tightening of monetary policy may be required to ensure that inflation returns to target in a reasonable timeframe, but that will depend upon the data and the evolving assessment of risks. "In making its decisions, the Board will continue to pay close attention to developments in the global economy, trends in household spending, and the outlook for inflation and the labour market."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another rate rise may be needed, Philip Lowe says

children.content: Despite hitting the pause button again this month, the
RBA says another rate rise might be on the cards
in the future.
RBA governor Philip Lowe
says that all depends on how quickly inflation returns to that all-important 2-3% target.
Here's some of what he had to say in his statement:
"Some
further tightening of monetary policy may be required
to ensure that inflation returns to target in a reasonable timeframe, but that will depend upon the data and the evolving assessment of risks.
"In making its decisions, the Board will continue to pay close attention to developments in the global economy, trends in household spending, and the outlook for inflation and the labour market."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year. The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting. You can read more about what that means on our business blog.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank leaves cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent

featuredLink.title: Live: RBA leaves interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent

children.content: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year.
The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting.
You can read more about what that means on our business blog.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity, hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week. Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres". No injuries have been reported. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another drone has hit a Moscow high-rise tower

featuredLink.title: Moscow mayor accuses Ukraine of drone strike on city buildings

props.alt: A close up of exterior glass windows of a skyscrapper wich have been badly damaged on a small number of floors

The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity,
hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week
Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres".
No injuries have been reported.
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations. "From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says. "The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police say images shared on the dark web in 2014 led to their investigation

children.content: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations.
"From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says.

"The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."
